instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message:
Customer said it just stopped working (hehe!)

Opened it up, filthy, so I'm guessing a short burnt something.


Okay, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Sits at 12.59v for a few moments then drops to 12.12 then back up...

I traced it along the rail and reached <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, pin 6 is going up and down like crazy.... This connects to <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>::Pin21 which is also going up and down.

Does <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> feed power /into/ U&100::Pin21?

This would mean <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> is faulty right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message: Remove F7140 and see if 12.6V is stable.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message:
Once F7410 is removed Pin 1 delivers a stable 12.57v.
I took a measurement from a few different points on the Pin 1 side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message: Did we just break the rail into two segments for isolation, or is the F7140 faulty?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message: The board is trying to turn on, this is when PPBUS drops to 12.12V. Is CPU Vcore coming on? Any shorts on any of the coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Green/Orange Light, No Power.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 6517"]Is CPU Vcore coming on? Any shorts on any of the coils?[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> was fluctuating so I was measuring around, and suddenly the fan turned on...

Reassembled the machine and it boots every time now. Take the wins when you get them I guess. :)
